text:
Pregnancy and labor do not discriminate on those usually enveloped in glitz and glamour. Even celebrity mothers have learned that birth doesn’t always go as planned. Take Amy Poehler, who’s doctor died the day before her due date. Or Kristen Bell, who had a very crazy reaction coming off her epidural. And then there’s Pink and Jill (Duggar) Dillard, who discovered that sometimes, your baby has a different idea of how he wants to come into this world.

Here are seven celebrity birth stories that will surprise you, make you giggle, or give you those sentimental feels.

Amy Poehler | A Due Date Disaster

The SNL alum recounts her first pregnancy experience back in 2008 in her book Yes Please, gushing over her old Italian doctor saying, “I was so lucky to have Dr. G as my doctor. I didn’t feel neurotic or stressed. I felt like a success.”

Then, the day before her due date she took a break from rehearsing for SNL to confirm her OB-GYN appointment and received the shock of her life.

“I hung up the phone and told Jon [Hamm] and the hair and makeup people that my doctor had just DIED. And I was DUE TOMORROW.”

If that’s not a nightmare, we don’t know what is. Luckily Poehler pulled herself together and went on to deliver a healthy baby boy (named Archibald “Archie” William Emerson) with the help of another doctor and a C-section.

Jill (Duggar) Dillard | A 70-Hour Labor

If anyone knows a thing or two about giving birth — it’s the Duggars. New mom Jill, who is studying to become a midwife, was very prepared for the birth of her firstborn earlier this year. In a special birth episode of 19 Kids and Counting, we were reminded once more that giving birth doesn’t always go as planned.

Jill had a very extensive natural birth plan. She readied two midwives in her own home and explained she would be willing to have her child naturally in a birthing tub, bath tub, or shower. Yet, when the time came for Jill to become a mom, her birth plans were thrown out the window.

She experienced 70 HOURS OF LABOR and ended up having a C-section in the hospital. During the episode, Jill gushed of her newborn son Israel David, “He’s worth every contraction. Every pain that I had all this long labor. Just getting to see that little baby and hold him, everything, [was] just … well worth it.”

Giuliana Rancic | A Successful Surrogacy

The longtime E! News host opened up about her fertility struggles on her show Giuliana and Bill and in her book Going Off Script. She documents the shots she had to receive in her stomach each day and the pain of having her ovaries overstimulated. How she suffered a miscarriage with her first IVF, and how the second attempt didn’t take.

Then when preparing to go through another egg retrieval, a routine mammogram revealed that she had breast cancer. Doctors warned her it would be dangerous to try and get pregnant, so the couple moved on to surrogacy.

In describing the moment she first held her son, Edward Duke, born via a surrogate in 2012, she writes:

“As I held our baby in that Denver delivery room, it was truly remarkable to think that … I had experienced the darkest days of my life and now, the brightest and most beautiful day of my life. I finally had what I wanted most, and every moment felt too precious to waste.”

Rancic’s story is a powerful and encouraging one to all of those struggling with infertility.

Beyoncé | A New Way to Get Through Labor Pains

Queen Bey’s little girl is known for her unique moniker, Blue Ivy Carter, but have you ever heard about Beyoncé’s birthing experience? Back in 2012, it was treated with the anticipation of a royal birth, because in a way it kind of was. The singer spoke to Marie Claire about giving birth and how she found a new way to get through the pain, explaining:

“I felt very maternal around eight months […] and I thought I couldn’t become anymore until I saw the baby. […] But it happened during my labor because I had a very strong connection with my child. I felt like when I was having contractions, I envisioned my child pushing through a very heavy door. And I imagined this tiny infant doing all the work, so I couldn’t think about my own pain. […] We were talking. I know it sounds crazy, but I felt a communication.”

Doesn’t seem that farfetched — more like a great way to get through the pain. She’s the Queen for a reason, right?

Kate Middleton | A Speedy Birth — and Recovery

The Duchess of Cambridge carried herself so well during her pregnancies, one may not have even noticed she suffered terribly from hyperemesis gravidarum. Her recent birth of daughter, Princess Charlotte, was certainly a quick one. It is said that the royal couple arrived at the hospital around 5 AM and the baby was born a mere two-and-a-half hours later — most likely without an epidural. Go Kate go! Always the classiest, the couple toasted the birth of their daughter with champagne.

Yet, the part we find the craziest in this whole event is the fact that Kate was standing on the steps of the hospital waving to onlookers less than ten hours after giving birth. Talk about a quick recovery!

Kristen Bell | An Excellent Epidural

Thanks to hubby Dax Shepard, we’ve all heard about Kristen Bell’s C-section with daughter Delta last year, in which Shepard exclaimed, “‘It’s a girl! Your liver’s out, I think! And those are definitely intestines. And she has your eyes. Oh, my God, put her back together correctly!”

However, Bell’s take on the event is just as amusing.

She told Ellen DeGeneres that as she came off her epidural she started “scratching her face … like a meth addict.” When a nurse gave her some Benadryl to ease the transition, Bell started to feel a little wacky, commenting, “Do you know what looks really good when you’re on that stuff? Hand bags. Or throw pillows or rugs. I was just like, ‘Internet shopping, woo!’”

After that mind-altering experience, Bell said she’s done having kids. “We don’t want to be outnumbered,” she explained. “We’re gonna cap it at two.”

Pink | A Natural Birth Plan That Wasn’t

Pink and her husband Carey Hart were very excited about their natural birth plan with daughter Willow Sage back in 2011. They watched documentaries about it and took all kinds of classes to prepare. Pink told People magazine, “I was really looking forward to the whole rite of passage — giving birth perfectly present, unmedicated, in the way nature intended.”

Well, the birth certainly didn’t go as planned. The baby was in the Frank breech position and no matter what the couple did, they couldn’t turn her around, so after two nights of labor she was delivered via C-section.

Pink explained, “Turns out this little girl had other plans — she is my daughter, after all.”
title: 7 Celebrity Birth Stories That Will Make You Laugh, Cry, or Give You the Feels
